docs.lead_paragraph: THIS village, its residents say, has a long history of caring. The Ossining Children's Center is currently celebrating its 100th anniversary; the Open Door Family Health Center here provided low-cost medical care to 7,500 Ossining residents last year, while other nonprofit groups concerned with food, affordable housing and child care served one-third of Ossining's population of 22,600 in 1995. But the intricate web of services that has helped people like Tasha Gonzalez, a 23-year-old single mother of twins, to work toward a better life may crumble under the impact of the country's new welfare law. Anticipating the chaos that may follow if social service agencies lose all or most of their Federal, state and county funds, representatives of eight of the agencies recently formed the Ossining Safety Net Committee.

headline.main: Ossining Agencies Unite to Gain a Stronger Voice for the Needy

docs.abstract: Eight anti-poverty and social-service agencies in Ossining, NY, unite, anticipating chaos that may follow if social service agencies lose all or most of their Federal, state and county funds under nation's new welfare law; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THIS village, its residents say, has a long history of caring. The Ossining Children's Center is currently celebrating its 100th anniversary; the Open Door Family Health Center here provided low-cost medical care to 7,500 Ossining residents last...

docs.lead_paragraph: She has a ruddy Irish face that blushes when she laughs, which is frequently, but don't let that fool you. Sister Jane Frances Brady, the chief executive officer of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in downtown Paterson, is one tough cookie. ''There are a lot of good people, and I like to think well of everyone,'' she said, discussing the growing problem of providing medical care for people in New Jersey with no health insurance. ''The thing that really bothers me, though, is that there are people who literally do not care, even a little bit, whether the poor get medical care or not.''

headline.main: A Pile of Medical Bills and a Heap of Politics

docs.abstract: Jersey column interviews Sister Jane Frances Brady, chief executive of St Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, on plight of people without medical coverage; she notes that 14 percent of people in state, mostly the working poor, are now uninsured (S)
docs.snippet: She has a ruddy Irish face that blushes when she laughs, which is frequently, but don't let that fool you. Sister Jane Frances Brady, the chief executive officer of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in downtown Paterson, is one tough cookie.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT LONG AGO, A CLASS OF HARVARD GRADUATE students joined their distinguished professor in a study of public attitudes toward welfare. That is, they opened their notebooks and switched on a tape of ''Oprah.'' Things got nasty fast.
docs.abstract: Jason DeParle article traces path of David Ellwood's welfare reform plan from his emphasis on personal responsibility, job training and time limits to final version that cuts off cash benefits; Harvard economist discusses disillusionment with political process at hands of Clinton Administration and conservative Republicans, 'corruption' of his original thoughts on ending generational dependency, and his concern for welfare children; interview; photos; he recalls privileged upbringing in Minneapolis suburb, in family with tradition of public service; Ellwood's father, Dr Paul Ellwood, envisioned health maintenance organizations and formed Jackson Hole Group which has championed managed care (M)
docs.snippet: NOT LONG AGO, A CLASS OF HARVARD GRADUATE students joined their distinguished professor in a study of public attitudes toward welfare. That is, they opened their notebooks and switched on a tape of ''Oprah.''    Things got nasty fast.

docs.lead_paragraph: TUCKED NEAR THE END OF A WINDING PRIVATE road above Jackson Hole, Wyo., is a house that is more a monument than a home. Its towering entrance is meant to evoke a Shinto temple. Its walls of windows are designed to capture the soaring views of the Tetons. Its living room is anchored by six majestic pillars. Thirty feet high, they are the trunks of 200-year-old spruce trees, still bearing scars from the Yellowstone fires of 1988. The house belongs to Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., who has quietly and incrementally helped transform American medicine over the past 25 years. Four years ago, he founded the Jackson Hole Group, the champion of managed health care in this country, and this house is a paean to that cause. It was built during the brief moment when health care reform was at the top of the national political agenda and when everyone who was anyone was making the trek to visit Ellwood, the man who started it all.
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin article on Dr Paul M Ellwood Jr, medical thinker who has incrementally transformed American medicine over past 25 years with his ideas about managed care; interview; photos; 70-year-old physician founded Jackson Hole Group and is father of Harvard economist David Ellwood, who developed welfare reform ideas (M)
